title: A Talk With Yellen, and Debt Payments From Venezuela Are Due
summary: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, heads to the University of Michigan for a conversation with the economist Susan M. Collins.

title: G.M. Takes a Back Seat to Tesla as America’s Most Valued Carmaker
summary: General Motors has achieved steady profits in a booming domestic market and has tried to prove its innovative approach, but investors are unimpressed.

title: Cathay Pacific to Replace Chief Executive as Losses Mount
summary: The airline, one of Asia’s biggest full-service carriers, has been battered by its bets on fuel prices as intense competition from low-cost carriers has risen.

title: Venezuela Staves Off Default, but Low Oil Prices Pose a Threat
summary: With dwindling reserves and political turmoil, the government is juggling assets and leaning on its American subsidiary, Citgo, to meet payment needs.

title: Bigger, Faster, More Lavish: Americans Crave S.U.V.s, and Carmakers Oblige
summary: At the New York International Auto Show, powerful sport utility vehicles are at center stage, a sign of the continuing shift away from traditional passenger cars.

title: Germany Strikes Offshore Wind Deals, Subsidy Not Included
summary: The Danish company Dong Energy has won the right to build two North Sea wind projects without government subsidies, a first for the industry.

title: Emerging Market Stocks Have Come Roaring Back. Can They Go Any Higher?
summary: A surge in commodity prices fueled a powerful rally in emerging-market stocks. But any further advances may have to come from other factors.

title: Investing in Solar and Wind in a Coal and Oil Moment
summary: Despite the Trump administration’s support for coal and other carbon fuels, there is a reasonable case for investing in renewable energy.

title: BP Struggles to Control Damaged Well in Alaskan Arctic
summary: Crews have been battling frigid winds to secure the well, which began spewing natural gas vapors on Friday. No injuries were reported.

title: Amid Venezuela Protests, G.M. Plant Is Seized, and Company Exits
summary: Street protests, shortages, currency restrictions and the constant threat of government expropriation have left foreign companies planning to leave.

title: Trump Rides a Market Wave, but Business Looks for Results
summary: Talk of a corporate tax cut helped fuel a stock rally, but executives say it is too soon to judge whether the president can deliver on his promises.

title: Europe’s Central Bank Sounds a More Upbeat Tone
summary: The central bank’s Governing Council has become more optimistic about the eurozone economy, offering a hint at winding down stimulus measures.

title: Trump Administration’s Push for Gas Exports Faces Market Glut
summary: Efforts to ramp up shipments could be complicated by a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Canadian Diners Reveal Their Special Places
summary: Readers find their most interesting and memorable dining experiences not just in pricey special-occasion restaurants but also in unassuming bistros and coffee shops.

title: Michel Temer Government in Brazil Reels as Dozens Face New Graft Investigations
summary: The ruling by a judge on Brazil’s Supreme Court allows prosecutors to start new inquiries of at least eight ministers in Mr. Temer’s cabinet and much of the senate.

title: A Trump Tower Neighbor Is the Point Man for Europe’s Populists
summary: George Guido Lombardi offers the intoxicating possibility of access to President Trump to Europe’s energized right-wing politicians.

title: Armed Civilian Bands in Venezuela Prop Up Unpopular President
summary: Members of the so-called collectives, or colectivos in Spanish, operate with impunity and will defend their besieged president at all costs, experts say.

title: Saudi Arabia Restores Public Sector Perks Amid Grumbling
summary: King Salman also promoted his sons Prince Khaled bin Salman as ambassador to the U.S. and Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman as state minister for energy affairs.

title: A Refuge for Orangutans, and a Quandary for Environmentalists
summary: Some worry that a palm oil company’s gift to endangered Borneo orangutans distracts from a big threat to the species: deforestation by such companies.

title: In Angolan Town, Land Mines Still Lurk ‘Behind Every Bush’
summary: Angola remains one of the world’s most heavily mined countries, and nowhere are there more than in Cuito Cuanavale.

title: In Mexico, an Epidemic of Fuel Thefts Becomes a Crisis
summary: The pilfering of gasoline for sale on the black market has soared in recent years, backed by criminal groups using bribery and violence.

title: In Mexico, ‘It’s Easy to Kill a Journalist’
summary: The state of Veracruz is the hemisphere’s most dangerous place to be a reporter. The authorities seem ill equipped to stop attacks on the press, and in some cases appear entangled in them.

title: Despite the ‘Yuck Factor,’ Leeches Are Big in Russian Medicine
summary: Russians use about 10 million leeches a year to treat heart disease, glaucoma, prostatitis, hypertension and even lower back pain.

title: Efforts to Ease Congestion Threaten Street Food Culture in Southeast Asia
summary: Major cities in Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia are forcing vendors to move, creating more space but diluting local flavor.

title: As Economy Grows, North Korea’s Grip on Society Is Tested
summary: The sign of life is a double-edged sword for Kim Jong-un, the nation’s leader, because information is seeping in along with foreign goods to marketplaces.

title: Dialogue With Iran Is Impossible, Saudi Arabia’s Defense Minister Says
summary: Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who is second in line to the throne, accused Iran of seeking to control the Muslim world and dismissed the idea of reconciliation.

title: Worry in Scorched Fort McMurray: How Many Will Walk Away?
summary: A year after a huge wildfire forced everyone in Canada’s oil sands city to flee, some who lost houses are choosing to take insurance payouts and move on rather than rebuild.

title: In Venezuela’s Chaos, Elites Play a High-Stakes Game for Survival
summary: Worsening unrest and economic collapse give powerful officials reason to want a change in leadership and an opportunity to impose it.

title: President Buhari’s Prolonged Absences Put Nigeria on Edge
summary: President Muhammadu Buhari’s medical leave at a time when Nigeria faces serious problems has raised questions about who exactly is in charge.

title: Pipelines and Donald Trump: British Columbia Goes to the Polls
summary: A Canadian province votes, with President Trump’s trade disputes in mind, as well as high housing prices and an investigation into campaign finances.

title: At Russia’s Victory Day Parade, Vladimir Putin Calls for Alliance
summary: The Russian president urged international cooperation against terrorism, but foreign leaders stayed away from Victory Day celebrations in Red Square.

title: Green Party Is Poised to Shift Power Balance in British Columbia
summary: With its progressive, environmentalist platform, the party earned three legislative seats in the province, denying a majority to the party in power since 2001.
